verses.verse: (Paul Goes to Macedonia and Greece) (Acts 11.26; 1 Cor 16.5; 1 Tim 1.3) After the uproar had ceased, Paul sent for the disciples, and after encouraging them and saying farewell, he left for Macedonia.
When he had gone through those regions and had given them much encouragement, he came to Greece,

(v 19|ACT 20:19; Acts 23.12; 25.3; 2 Cor 11.26) where he stayed for three months. He was about to set sail for Syria when a plot was made against him by the Jews, so he decided to return through Macedonia.

(Acts 16.1; 19.29; 21.29; 27.2; Eph 6.21; Col 4.7; 2 Tim 4.12, 20; Titus 3.12) He was accompanied (Other ancient authorities add as far as Asia) by Sopater son of Pyrrhus from Beroea, by Aristarchus and Secundus from Thessalonica, by Gaius from Derbe, and by Timothy, as well as by Tychicus and Trophimus from Asia.
They went ahead and were waiting for us in Troas,
(Acts 16.8; 2 Cor 2.12; 2 Tim 4.13) but we sailed from Philippi after the days of Unleavened Bread, and in five days we joined them in Troas, where we stayed for seven days.

(Paul’s Farewell Visit to Troas) (1 Cor 16.2; Rev 1.10) On the first day of the week, when we met to break bread, Paul was holding a discussion with them; since he intended to leave the next day, he continued speaking until midnight.
There were many lamps in the room upstairs where we were meeting.

A young man named Eutychus, who was sitting in the window, began to sink off into a deep sleep while Paul talked still longer. Overcome by sleep, he fell to the ground three floors below and was picked up dead.
(1 Kings 17.21; Mt 9.23, 24) But Paul went down and bending over him took him in his arms and said, “Do not be alarmed, for his life is in him.”
Then Paul went upstairs, and after he had broken bread and eaten, he continued to converse with them until dawn; then he left.
Meanwhile they had taken the boy away alive and were not a little comforted.
(The Voyage from Troas to Miletus) We went ahead to the ship and set sail for Assos, intending to take Paul on board there, for he had made this arrangement, intending to go by land himself.
When he met us in Assos, we took him on board and went to Mitylene.

We sailed from there, and on the following day we arrived opposite Chios. The next day we touched at Samos, and (Other ancient authorities add after remaining at Trogyllium) the day after that we came to Miletus.

(Acts 2.1; 18.19; 19.21; 21.4, 12; 1 Cor 16.8) For Paul had decided to sail past Ephesus, so that he might not have to spend time in Asia; he was eager to be in Jerusalem, if possible, on the day of Pentecost.
(Paul Speaks to the Ephesian Elders) (Acts 11.30) From Miletus he sent a message to Ephesus, asking the elders of the church to meet him.
(Acts 18.19) When they came to him, he said to them: “You yourselves know how I lived among you the entire time from the first day that I set foot in Asia,
serving the Lord with all humility and with tears, enduring the trials that came to me through the plots of the Jews.
(v 27) I did not shrink from doing anything helpful, proclaiming the message to you and teaching you publicly and from house to house,
(Acts 2.38; 18.5; 24.24) as I testified to both Jews and Greeks about repentance toward God and faith toward our Lord Jesus. (Other ancient authorities add Christ)
(v 16) And now, as a captive to the Spirit, (Or And now, bound in the spirit) I am on my way to Jerusalem, not knowing what will happen to me there,
(Acts 21.4, 11) except that the Holy Spirit testifies to me in every city that imprisonment and persecutions are waiting for me.

(Acts 21.13; 2 Cor 4.16; Gal 1.1; Titus 1.3) But I do not count my life of any value to myself, if only I may finish my course and the ministry that I received from the Lord Jesus, to testify to the good news of God’s grace.
(v 38) “And now I know that none of you, among whom I have gone about proclaiming the kingdom, will ever see my face again.
(Acts 18.6; 2 Cor 7.2) Therefore I declare to you this day that I am not responsible for the blood of any of you,
(Acts 13.36) for I did not shrink from declaring to you the whole purpose of God.

(1 Cor 12.28; 1 Tim 4.16; 1 Pet 1.19) Keep watch over yourselves and over all the flock, of which the Holy Spirit has made you overseers, to shepherd the church of God (Other ancient authorities read of the LORD) that he obtained with the blood of his own Son. (Or with his own blood; Gk with the blood of his Own)
(Mt 7.15) I know that after I have gone, savage wolves will come in among you, not sparing the flock.
Some even from your own group will come distorting the truth in order to entice the disciples to follow them.
(Acts 19.10) Therefore be alert, remembering that for three years I did not cease night or day to warn everyone with tears.

(Acts 14.23; Col 1.12; 3.24; 1 Pet 1.4) And now I commend you to God and to the message of his grace, a message that is able to build you up and to give you the inheritance among all who are sanctified.
(1 Cor 9.12; 2 Cor 7.2; 11.9; 12.17) I coveted no one’s silver or gold or clothing.
(Acts 18.3) You know for yourselves that I worked with my own hands to support myself and my companions.

(Rom 15.1) In all this I have given you an example that by such work we must support the weak, remembering the words of the Lord Jesus, for he himself said, ‘It is more blessed to give than to receive.’ ”
(Acts 9.40; 21.5) When he had finished speaking, he knelt down with them all and prayed.
(Gen 45.14) There was much weeping among them all; they embraced Paul and kissed him,
(v 25|ACT 20:25; Acts 15.3) grieving especially because of what he had said, that they would not see him again. Then they brought him to the ship.
